Therefore, everybody is speculating about the chances but also the threats by AI. But who gives substantial orientation? After reading „Life 3.0: Being Human in the Age of Artificial Intelligence“ by Max Tegmark (a very helpful hint by my former Pixelpark colleague Barbara Daliri Freyduni) I followed the recommendation of serial founder and AI-expert Stephan Uhrenbacher (FLIO.com Digital Airports, Qype, 9flats.com) to read the current Bestseller “Prediction Machines” from Ajay Agrawal, Joshua Gans and Avi Golfarb. As a fellow at Creative Destruction Lab (CDL), a high profiled accelerator focused on Machine Learning in Toronto, Stephan got in personal touch with these three economists from at the University of Toronto's Rotman School of Management, who have cofounded CDL, and supported their publication. Based on various empiric studies and their personal insights from working with AI-pioneers at CDL Agrawal, Gans and Golfarb explain why prediction machines makes predictions better, faster and increasingly cheaper and become extremely powerful but as well with specific limitations. They conclude: The combination of humans and machines generates best results by compensating the differing weaknesses of both. How does such a collaboration translate into a business environment? In two ways: (1) The machine provides an initial prediction that humans can combine and use for their own assessment, judgement and decision making or (2) The machines provide parallel or afterwards a second opinion which helps e.g. higher-level managers to ensure high performance of their employees Agrawal, Gans Golfarb reflect extensively also the different types of risks carried by AI, but they inspire in a pragmatic way to think about the new opportunities in an open way. A must-read for everybody who wants to understand the economic logic of AI-power behind the technical development.

As industry expert, I would say this is the best book analyzing AI economic implications.It has a great AI characterization, as prediction algorithms, and a super suitable analysis framework, based on the new trade offs that cheaper prediction will generate (in opposition to theoretical and unsustained predictions) in terms of business strategy and society.I can not recommend it more! Indeed, I have bought copies for everybody at my company.

Started out well, but doesn't justify its length. And it's not really that long.The authors seem to have an agenda to promote machine learning algorithms. Part of the book educated the reader about what these algorithms can do. But as a practitioner, I can see some places where they are overstating their case. The biggest example is they state that the 2008 financial crisis could possibly have been avoided by machine learning algorithms because they would not have had the same biases as the analysts who built the regression models. There's no reason to think that this is the case; we've seen that machine learning algorithms succumb to bias just as easily as traditional models. The authors themselves cite the Tay chatbot and racial profiling algorithms. Since this sketchy claim about the 2008 financial crisis came at page 36, I had a skeptic's eye throughout the rest of the book.So it's better to read this book as the case for more machine learning. I was pretty unimpressed. After a while, I felt like I was right in the middle of a machine learning bubble with inflated expectations. The "hockey stick" charts on page 159 were a low point: the authors were asserting that machine learning would be picked up by other industries later than tech industries for the same reason that hybrid corn was adopted later by Alabama than it was by earlier states. This was an unconvincing analogy. It made me worry that I should look for a new career because there are likely lots of young students right now trying to learn machine learning algorithms and hoping to compete for the same number of jobs that I am.Despite these complaints, it's still a good introduction to machine learning. The first two chapters are especially good. You might want to stop there; after that, there is a lot of cherry-picking to make machine learning look better than what I've seen in my career.

Artificial Intelligence is definitely on its way. This book did a good job demonstrating how it works in terms of machine learning. I found the concepts intriguing. As an IT person, its easy to view AI as the proverbial IF statement. Even though lots of code is object orientated and sensor driven. The concepts discuss talked above how much more important that a machines ability to learn was than predefined algorithms that are not flexible to take input and derive solutions to unforeseen obstacles. It did separate AI from AGI (Artificial General Intelligence). AI being a developed structure of learning versus AGI being self contained structure of learning that extend outside of the predefined learning limits.It talked about the upsides of AI and the extension of the poverty level because of AI destroying jobs, the rich getting richer. It was interesting to hear how Elon Musk, Mister SpaceX, and Mister Microsoft, Bill Gates were against the advancement of AI because of how it would effect the economic welfare of the average person. Some things were some what alarming like a prediction that China would dominate the world in AI merely because of the money, billions, that they are sinking into AI and the inhumane treatment of their people would lead to them using their citizens as guinea pigs for AI analysis. How hackers could hack medical devices and possible real havoc on people. How they could hack self-driving cars. And worse of all how an evil terrorist could hack your wifi toaster and burn your toast just to use the computing power.The book was interesting made lots of interesting observations and was worth the time required to read.

The book was interesting, the perspective of economists explaining the artificial inteligence and machind learning is not very focus on the economical side. A few things on why I liked the book: - the reference to Moneyball just makes it much easier to relate to the fact that predictive machine learning is not so intangibile. - I liked the story with the search query “hiybbprqag” that does not actually exist and forced Google engineers to use Bing, which is Microsoft’s search engine. Than after running a new search on Google it actually referenced Bing searches for the same. - I also liked the story with Uber and black cabs, which were very precious for their good knowledge of London’s street, peak hours jams and that were replaced by GPS. Interesting enough this did not left black cabs drivers without a job, it just provided equal chances to non black cab drivers and drive the price down. - I enjoyed the idea with Amazon’s strategy challenge to change from shopping to shipping into shipping to shopping. First deliver and them return what is not useful. This means to have a very good predictive machine learning that would learn user’s preferences and will encourage shopping, hopefully with less returns. - Tim Cook’s statement on Apple’s home page - that shows a commitment to privacy data protection despite of maybe losing the data needed to improve predictions Why did I gave it 3 stars? Because I felt it could be written in more dynamic way, I got a bit bored sometimes and was just looking to jump to a more meaningful information. I also think it is easier to relate to real life examples

Insightful and timely book discussing the implications of artificial intelligence for business and society.For the last couple of years as distributed computing has advanced in power and ease of use I have increasingly felt the technology is being wildly underestimated by most people. This book addresses a critical topic.The name of the book frames the discussion. Rather than use existing terms like artificial intelligence or big data the term "prediction" is used to emphasize a particularly significant aspect of recent development likely to have an out-sized impact on society. There are many examples that illustrate transformational improvements in processing capability leading to a discussion of business strategy.Examples are drawn from diverse fields Driving, Radiology, Warehousing, and Airlines.I think it is clever to highlight the productivity challenge of Robert Solow. This encourages us to think critically about the impact and application of the technology. The decomposition of work into tasks likely to be automated and those likely to be enhanced anticipates a massive process that will transform our lives.Here are a few of the ideas I thought were notable:The importance of understanding the reasoning for decisions informed by computer analysis. Implications for business strategy.Limitations and inherent risks of the technology.Impact the technology is likely to have on society.Overall I thought it was a very thoughtful and thought-provoking analysis.

Notes:The current wave of advances in AI doesn't actually bring us intelligence but instead a critical component of intelligence: prediction.Prediction is the process of filling in missing information. Prediction takes information you have, often called data, and uses it to generate information you don't have.We anticipate the rise in human prediction by exception whereby machines generate most predictions because they are predicated on routine, regular data, but when rare events occur the machine recognizes that it is not able to produce a prediction with confidence, and so calls for human assistance. The human provides by exception.While a machine predicts what is likely to happen, humans will still decide what action to take based on the understanding of the objective. In many situations, as with Waze, the machine will give the human a prediction that implies a certain outcome for one dimension (like speed); the human will then decide to overrule that (for example using the bathroom).Enhanced prediction enables decision makers to, whether human or machine, to handle more ifs and more thens. That leads to better outcomes.In the absence of good predictions , we do a lot of satisficing, making decisions that are good enough given the information.Perhaps the skill set of the employee formally known as a school bus driver will change. Drivers may act more like teachers than they do today. But the important point is that automation that eliminates a human from the task does not necessarily eliminate them from a job.

I will preface this by saying that I do not normally enjoy "business books," so 3 stars from me is like 5 stars for this category. My boss wanted everyone to read this book because he thoroughly believes this is the future, which is rapidly approaching. People often like to say, "if you're not on board, then you get left behind." With AI, it is not enough to just be on board, we all owe it to our careers to get educated to understand how our professions will rapidly change over the next few years.I appreciated that this book was written by economists and not technologists. It gave it a Freaknomics type feel, which made the reading more enjoyable, and helped me understand the macro impact of this technology. I'm not a data scientist so I don't know the details on how exactly the technology is evolving, and also I don't really care. I also enjoyed the anecdotes of how much of this technology is already integrated our lives. However, because of those anecdotes, I can see that this book will very quickly become outdated.Overall, interesting read. I think we owe it to ourselves to self enlighten regarding where this world is heading. It's also a little scary to think that, in a few short years, we will actually be concerned about robots outsmarting humans. The authors kept trying to assure us that human judgment will always be needed, but then follow up by saying how judgment can be programmed. It's all a little concerning.

Quite a realistic book on AI. No fantasy or sci-fi (unlike Nick Bostrom!), but practical and managerial considerations on using AI for business. Great insight with economics perspective!My favorite quotes:"Prediction Machines is not a recipe for success in the AI economy. Instead, we emphasize trade-offs. More data means less privacy. More speed means less accuracy. More autonomy means less control.""In contrast to machines, humans are sometimes extremely good at prediction with little data.""Humans are able to make analogies or recognize useful similarities in different contexts.""For every bomber that returned from bombing raids over Germany, the engineers could see where they had been hit by antiaircraft fire. The bullet holes in the planes were their data. But were these the obvious places to better protect the plane? They asked statistician Abraham Wald to assess the problem. After some thought and some rather thorough mathematics, he told them to protect the places without bullet holes.""However, many organizations have vague, multifaceted mission statements that lend themselves well to marketing brochures but not so well to identifying the prediction objective for an AI.""As better prediction reduces uncertainty, we use economics to tell you what AI means for the decisions you make in the course of your business."

What is the economic value of Artificial Intelligence (AI)? AI will make prediction cheap! When prediction becomes cheap, we will use it more and use it in ways that we have never done before! As computer made arithmetic cheap and thus transformed the way we work, AI will do the same thing for prediction which is defined as "the process of filling in missing information- taking information you have, data, and use it to generate information that you don't have.Prediction is in the heart of the process of decision making, but it is not everything. Making a decision requires applying judgement to prediction and then acting. Judgement - assigning a value to the decision outcome- will be the skill set needed and valued when prediction becomes cheap by AI automation of big data! Written by three economists from University of Toronto Rotman School of Business (and published by Harvard Business Review Press!), this book is a nice guide to understand what would be the near-future impact of AI on our life and how we are going to do business. As the authors have their feet on the ground working with science-based startups, they certainly deliver on their promise to "cut through the hype to focus on what technology means for decision making"!

Provides great insight and perspective on how to think about the impact of AI on business and the economy.It's written by an economist and does a good job of integrating the impacts of AI into economics and business. However, the writer does not display deep understanding of how ML impacts areas like robotics. The book frames AI as a significant reduction of price (and increased availability) of prediction. This can then be integrated into supply and demand dynamics, and interesting conclusions can be drawn. But the perspective communicated in the book is a bit like viewing AI as significantly improved spreadsheets. This is true. And to be fair, the author totally acknowledges and talks about the impact of improved prediction on machine vision and robotics. But the consequent impacts of those changes are not very well explored. A reader of Prediction Machines would not be surprised by improved shopping recommendations, but they would still be quite surprised by the cashierless checkout of Amazon Go.So Prediction Machines is a very good book and will help you with thinking about AI and it's applications. But it's a bit high level and doesn't get into some interesting details or extrapolations.

[my notes]Impact of ai: capital- when prediction is cheap enough to change strategic dilemmaAdvertisement:- Companies sell their cookies data to companies that place advertisement so they can target their ad for high-value customers-Google, Amazon, etc have good data on consumer preferences. Not only they sell data but also predictionsMedical field-Ai just plays as an input to the process. AI does not need to own the diagnosis. The doctor will!Judgment quality is difficult to specify in the contract:-Judgment is the key role for human labor. Therefore, in-house employment will rise and contracting out labour will fall. AI increase the incentive to own data. -Sometimes it is strategic to buy predictions than the data. This is where AI contract makes more sense.Prediction on the ground vs cloud: -faster content dependent learning at the cost of accurate predictions overall and to protect consumer privacy (apple)China does not care about privacy> Lots of personal data for trainingAGI: artificial general Intelligence =human like intelligence: - Cannot be achieved until decades. we don't need to worry about it. Although many companies raised lots of funding on this subject: (Google Deepmind, Vicarious, Kindred, etc)

The authors of this audiobook are economists who are professors at a university. The book reads like a textbook and sounds like lectures. It was quite interesting, though. It looked, from an economic standpoint, at the impact of the burgeoning use of AI. First it explained that the function of current AI is basically prediction and explained how improved prediction will and might impact business. The book explained why using AI to make predictions was likely to work better than humans and where humans would still be needed. It considered the expected societal issues of increased use of AI (as well as issues already occurring). It also stressed that there are many unknown unknowns that will result form the improving AI, using as an example how the GPS apps on smartphones decreased the need for London taxi drivers as it allowed untrained drivers (think UBER) to accomplish what had taken the traditional London taxi driver years to learn (the city of London and how best to get from one place in the City to another). One section that I found particularly interesting was about the data needed and used to train AI and how it could be flawed or biased.

This was a really mixed bag. On the positive side, it's an interesting exploration of the economic implications of improvements in prediction. I think they well overshoot the technical possibilities, but it points in some interesting directions for how things might change as AI advances. But those overshoots are a major flaw. In their world, AI will always work perfectly for the job and not suffer from any limitations once it has the training data it needs. They barely even consider the possibility that there will be other technical limitations. Their own favorite example, Tesla's Autopilot functionality, points to the flaws in the book. To the authors, Autopilot is a beautiful example of the possibilities of AI, once it has enough real world data to train on. But we have enough news stories about Autopilot failures that we know their version is lacking nuance. It's too bad - they have some good points lurking in the middle of it all, if only they could have tempered their predictions.

"We are continuously making low level predictions across our senses. But that's not all.I am arguing a much stronger proposition. Prediction is not just one of things your brain does, it is the primary function of the neocortex. It is the very foundation of intelligence. Cortex is the organ of prediction."Prediction Machines is a 200 or so page, layman friendly treatise on Machine Learning from an economist's lens. While not heavily delving into the science or the tech behind it, it serves as thought experiment on how the ability to make predictions is the new oil of the information economy. There are some really interesting topics and ideas, regarding the nature of prediction. How humans have always done it, to make decisions and how AI does it using data, and learning from it. And of course, there are plenty of really interesting case studies on the use of AI in streamlining numerous industries: from healthcare to the vast Taxi network in London.Much of the book is probably very obvious information for people in the field, but very eye opening for the new entrants like myself.

A somewhat reductive view of what AI is, considering only one part of "narrow" AI, namely prediction engines. With that said, it is an incisive set of considerations about what happens when prediction becomes more accurate, or at least perceived as more accurate. Some of the intuitions are non-obvious. For example, it creates relative scarcity (and thus higher valuation) of some things, like strategic judgment. It will make some kinds of outsourcing easier, though it will create new agent-principal problems around who has control over the interpretation of results. It will create new kinds of blindnesses, especially in people who do not understand the aporias in the data on top of which the prediction engines are being built. And finally, rather than eliminating jobs, it is likely to reshape jobs, as the prediction pieces go away and the more client-service pieces become more essential.

90 percent of this book is theory crafting with no solid conclusions. The authors repeatedly make the point that AI will make predictions cheaper thereby increasing the value of judgment which will be delivered by humans. But why stop there? Who's to say that algorithms won't further evolve to automate prescription as well and labor is shut-out completely? The authors arbitrarily select a convenient place in which AI stops evolving leaving humans with just enough to do. One example which made it really hard to take this book seriously was when the authors pitched the scenario in which self-driving school buses will reduce the demand for bus drivers but the driver won't lose his/her job because somebody still needs to supervise the kids on the bus. So you are telling me that after I invest my money in a self-driving school bus, I still have to keep the driver on my pay roll? Economists stay true to form with this book: Simplify everything, and confidently conclude nothing.

I’m not sure when machine learning (ML) began being used interchangeably with artificial intelligence (AI), but that should stop. It’s like sticking a 5G sticker on your 4G logo and saying you have the world’s fastest network - looking at you AT&T.Anyhow, the book is an okay read filled with carefully picked anecdotes that fit the author’s points and repeatedly drive home how economists are the best equipped to decipher the future of “prediction machines”/machine learning. Beyond understanding goods and supply/demand curves, I’m not convinced. Several of the points raised from an economist’s perspective are interesting and are worth thought, especially how different nations are poised for success in the field and how this may play to corporate tech/data monopolies and increased income inequality.If you’re someone who doesn’t understand tech or have a technical background but wants to learn more about machine learning (NOT AI) from an economical/business standpoint, worth a read.

This was an excellent primer on AI for business leaders, clearly and concisely addressing the positive, negative, and unknowable implications of implementing AI in your business, as well as the impact on global economies. There was a great emphasis on AI as PREDICTIVE technology and why that's so important in economics, something that I (not knowing much about economics in the first place) had never thought about before.The authors often referenced a thought experiment about how AI could transform amazon from a sell-then-ship company into a ship-then-sell company as their AI (hypothetically) got so good at predicting what consumers wanted that it became more profitable to ship them things and arrange returns than it was to just wait for consumers to buy it themselves first. I wish there had been more examples like this one, but it was effective and memorable.

A well-thought out and organised book. The writing is very clear and easy to understand with examples that genuinely illustrate the point being made. One of the few non-fiction books I've read that was truly well worth the time reading. I really like the summaries at the end of each chapter for two reasons. (1) The summaries are concise but with details where necessary. So (2) for chapters I wasn't sure I was interested in, after a few paragraphs, I'd go to the summary to see if there are points mentioned I want to read more of, and I'd find that part in the chapter to read. Saved me a lot of time and helped me remember what I'd read.Recommended this book to two friends immediately upon reading.

This is not a bad book, though it provides little that isn’t more thoroughly explained in several other books on machine learning and artificial intelligence. What I find particularly bad is that it presents itself as a guide to future developers, business owners and investors. If you have such aspirations, I encourage you to please read something else. Some of the recent introductory AI books I’d recommend are:Superintelligence by Nick BostonMachine, Platform, Crowd by Andrew McAfee Life 3.0 by Max TegmarkNot to mention all of the modern philosophy texts on reason and intelligence, which provide a much more thorough understanding of what challenges we face in both creating and directing artificial intelligence.

In a series of efforts to understand what AI means and what it actually can, I started reading books about artificial intelligence. This book argues AI is, in some sense, a prediction machine based on a large body of data. It is better than human beings at crunching numbers in a fast and accurate manner. Prediction, however, is not tantamount to judgment, valuation, let alone decision-making. It is far from causation. It is a mere correlation between events. It lacks cultural, political, ethical considerations to abide by. Despite all this shortcoming, it is here to stay affecting wage distribution and how work is organized. Do not ignore it at your own perils nor over-rejoice at its promises to your rude awakening.

A good summary of the impact of AI on business for anyone who hasn’t already been following it closely. If you have, you won’t find much that’s novel here, with the single exception of the authors’ economic perspective. Thinking of the product of AI as “prediction” and then looking at what this substitutes for, and what it’s complemented by, is something I haven’t seen much elsewhere. This said, this insight alone is not worth a book-length treatment. So if you’re already familiar with the business potential and risks of AI, you may want to skip the book and read a summary. But if you’re fairly new to the subject, this book is a good introduction with a unique take.

I am really sorry but I have to give a negative review of this book. There are three basic rules of me choosing a book: entertainment, educational, or escape my bubble. Unfortunately this book didn't provide me anything of those things. I should say that some of their facts are also wrong, especially in the history of computers/AI I was hoping to read about ELIZA in that chapter! I understand that this book is being written from an economists point of view and thus my expectations shouldn't be very high on a technical side, but this book just offers a simple overview of the current status in AI and nothing else. At least for me. Full disclosure I got this audiobook on a sale $3.66.

This book definitely helped me understand AI better. It did not help me feel secure in the future though. I don't have a business, but I was curious about how others thought it would play out in the economy, One critique I have of this book is that they focused on the short term, which makes sense due to its target audience, but I think we all know that many changes will be made and the economy will look very different then. That's probably why they kept it short term though.I liked how it talked about how the strategy will have to change with AI, and what humans could do to supplement it, but like I said earlier who knows how long that will even last.

A very interesting and multi-layered analysis of how AI might be practically deployed in business. I particularly liked the pyramid approach the authors took for the book - looking at the predictions made, how they were used in decision making, what tools could be used to bring about tangible changes, strategies that could be used, and finally, what the societal implications of AI technology are. That final point was dealt with pretty well - far less rhetoric about possible Skynet-esque futures than a lot of other AI books. Very analytical and evaluative, with a broad base of evidence to support a lot of the claims made.

Well structured book. Balanced for a diverse audience.If you're an academic or have been studying these concepts for a while, the content will be elementary but the book is still worth reading. The authors offer a lesson in how to communicate what ML & AI can (and can't) do to an executive audience. If you're new to this space, the book guides you through some of the latest thinking, starting with more foundational concepts and working its way up the pyramid to how it all fits tofether strategically.

A good primer on AI, with lots of good, illustrative examples. The authors describe how financial companies can spot credit card fraud, how better predictive analysis of X-rays can reduce the need for medical procedures like biopsies. and how Tesla takes into account your battery level when planning a route (it knows if you will need to recharge). It also looks at how AI works best in combination with human judgement, and tries to provide a framework for how you can think about AI projects. Clear, and easy to understand.

The authors have done a great job making this an easy to read book for anyone looking to learn more about the AI landscape. It's not meant to get into the nitty gritty details of how the actually technology works but instead discusses the impacts it will have on companies and businesses going forward. It uses many examples in its discussions which help you to understand the effects of other disruptions in the past. The book is structured very orderly, and touches on topics such as what 'prediction' really is, how it affects strategy, and how/whether it will replace jobs.

Good summary of the industry and future potential along with some salient points, though not much that was revolutionary in its thinking. "Superintelligence: Paths, Dangers, Strategies"by Nick Bostrom, has a much more influential narrative and way of contemplating complexity and impacts. This book does however serve as a good introduction, and articulates a good selection of case studies and impact through an economics lens; most of it was pretty familiar and it was only the last 2-3 chapters that I felt contained some "aha" moments and punch.

This is a pretty light volume aimed at helping mostly non-technical people understand how AI will affect them and their businesses. In traditional biz book style, the chapters are short and pointed, with bullet-list summaries of key points at the end, just so no one can miss them. I was hoping for more forward looking thoughts, but I guess that is not what this book is trying to do. As a primer on what AI is and how it works, not a bad book. Lots of good ideas about how to think about integrating AI into a business.

One good basic idea, lots of general low-insight paddingWell-written. Unfortunately, like most business books, fairly thin on ideas, with plenty of padding and generalizations. Could have been a good, meaty, magazine article.Mostly focused on their economist view that AI are prediction machines. The implication is that prediction, which is an important part of decision-making, will become suddenly much cheaper, and so any tasks, processes, or jobs that involve prediction will have to be rethought.

This book is really amazing. it takes you in the journey of how to understand the other sides of the machine learning. It is not computer science book that you will understand about the machine learning techniques but you will understand how non computer science related people look at this field from outside.It has an excellent feature from the writers is they provide after each chapter a summary as key points to sum up the ideas discussed in the chapter.Really informative and well written book

Overall its a great book, with synergistic insights between economics and AI/machine learning. I specially enjoyed all the analogies and practical examples. However, I think the mental model to think of all that AI does as predictions is a helpful start, but hits the limits at times. For instance, the many RL models, take into account things like curiosity and intrinsic motivations for no better reason than it fits some tasks at hand. Also, The way I see it, the economics of AI is isn't quite that 'simple' since AI agents of today aren't all that rational.

Written from an economists perspective, Prediction Machines focuses on the question of how organizations and society will be affected by the decreasing cost of prediction, what role humans will play in an AI based economy (judgment), and the risks and benefits of implementing AI in an organization. A good read on the economic implications of AI/ML for anyone looking for a non-technical, business perspective on the issue.

Great overview of the current AI/Machine Learning landscape circa 2018.Premise of the book is that AI can be evaluated via a framework of providing needs and by the types of data used to fuel the training, feedback and ongoing model needs.Comes to the table with an Economics approach. If the cost of predicting something approaches zero, business will use it constantly. The nature of data builds a strong moat that can be hard to breach. This can favor the first mover.

The book can be summarized in one sentence: AI dramatically lowers the price of prediction. The rest is about various economic consequences of this effect for companies, employees, and consumers. There are a lot of concrete and insightful examples that made me really think. But, overall, the book feels a bit fluffy and most of its most interesting content could probably fit into one or two blog posts.

The authors of Prediction Machines use basic economic theory to explain what we should expect to happen due to recent progress in AI. This is the most level-headed exploration of the topic I have seen. The central economic idea they make use of is that if a product becomes cheaper, the complementary products become more valuable. The product in question is prediction. One of the most important complements is human judgement.

A very enlightening book that was able to bring forth the pros and cons of using AI aka Data Science in management, businesses and policies.The examples are apt, easy to relate. More importantly, I like how the authors cleverly also structured and presented explanation of how AI works in layman and relatable analogies to let the reader better appreciate and maybe make one less fearful of the unknowns.

One of the first books on business strategy in times of Artificial Intelligence. The contents provide a theoretical framework of reference to outline a strategy, not a framework at an implementation level (that is still years aways as we continue to experiment both, in terms of technology and business applications).The language used in the book is very approachable, however technical knowledge of basic AI concepts can help to contextualize the ideas that the authors try to transmit.

Clear, Interesting and UsefulThree academic economists who run an incubator for AI startups present and justify simple principles for evaluating the potential of today's machine learning technology in any discipline. This book is an easy and enjoyable read enlivened by many interesting examples, both real-world and hypothetical. Business people, students, researchers and technologists will all find it worthwhile.

It was a solid read. First you read Superintelligence by Nick Bostrom and then you're like: "OH FUCK ROBOTS WILL TAKE OVER US THEY WILL IMPROVE THEMSELVES AND KILL US ALL FUCKHELP", and then you read this book and you understand that most of "AI" based things are generally just prediction machines, that NEED data in order to become mildly competitive in the field of prediction. Looks like Artificial General Intelligence is kind of far for now. Chill.

Better than I expected. The author does not just talk about how this work but how prediction machines will change our day to day lives. Some of the starting prediction machine examples are really cool. And he breaks down step by step to explain how this can be practically achieved by prediction machines. I would recommend anyone who is curious about how AI will change/impact our day to day life in the coming years.

An interesting read and a fresh, realistic view of AI in the marketplace and its impact. There were some great points made, but much was repetitive and could have been condensed. I skipped several paragraphs on many pages. I still recommend this to anyone interested in this field or part of business and I have already brought up a few points from this book in business conversations within days of finishing it.

A thorough and well composed description of the new business tools that spring from machine learning. Instead of talking about neural networks, artificial intelligence or regression, the authors cleverly use the term "prediction machine". By focusing on using machines to make predictions and applying an economist's lens to the dynamics around the technology, an interesting landscape emerges with some indications on how to apply predictions machines in decision making.

A must read for everyone who is not a techie and needs to get a perspective about AI.This is an amazing book for all the people looking to know about what the AI buzz is about. It’s perfect for those who are not techies but want to build an understanding about AI. Brilliant content !

Wow. Complicated concept in a simple-to-consume document. Key points are summarized at the end of the chapter which helps me retain information, like a modified cornell notes. But AI, so many applications and the future pretty vivid. I can’t help but be inspired by it, but also fear it - the fear stems from the fallibility of the human condition.

Great read to get an overview about AI and how it is and will continue to influence economics. As the author states, prediction is just one of the components of intelligence, and we're still far far away from General AI :) Very interesting insight about scale economies, data and consequences. Author gives a lot of interesting examples that help give context to what is exposed. Recommended!

A solid book to start understanding what is AI and its implications for businesses. The book is not technical and it is easy to understand regardless of your academic background or work experience. It is a solid book for those who are not familiar with the topic, but it also has good insights if you already have some experience.Overall a good read, I would recommend it

Good overview to get an overall perspective of prediction, AI and machine learning. It does a good job not only to play the hype of AI but tries to identify potential issues to better manage expectations from the exciting technologies. Highly recommended for top-level executives to better understand AI and its role in their businesses.

This will be enlightening to any one in modern business with only light technology skills. It doesn’t dive deep enough into any one framework to feel flushed out. Worth a read if you’re in management and need a primer. Some cause and effect scenarios are semi provocative, but this will likely go into a shelf, never to be reached for again.

A good introduction to predictive machine learning and its possible uses in business, health and other industries. However this book doesn’t delve into the methods, nor does it deeply examine some of the weaknesses and gaps in the science. Worth reading as an intro course, but I was hoping for more.

Cool book about AI that tells AI is not Skynet but Terminators might come sooner or later. It focuses on prediction machines leaving judgement for human beings...at the moment.Nice and quick reading introducing AI. Not a manual or skin deep analysis but gets straight to the point. Read it. I do not think you’ll be disappointed.

This was written for business audiences, from the perspective of economists who run an incubator for AI startups. Not for arm chair experts, and the middle of the book drags a bit. However lots of awesome arguments are made for why hysteria is yet unwarranted, and some great insights are raised that broadened my view of the business and societal implications of the pending technology revolution.

This is probably a 1.5 as the book isn't unreadable, it's just not particularly informative about prediction machines aka ai or as far as I can tell how to use them in your business. I don't own a business admittedly, nor am I a manager, so maybe this is useful but it seems incredibly dumbed down and I mostly feel like I waster 7 hours or how ever long it took me to get through it.

Different take on AI by looking at the economics of AI, not the technical "how it works." Great way to look at the business value of AI and how to discuss with executives and line or mission managers. I really appreciate the different perspective that the value of AI is in its ability to commoditize prediction freeing humans in the loop to exercise judgment. Highly recommended read!

This is good overview of how machine learning can impact your business by defining AI as simply a prediction tool. Written by economists, Prediction Machines is an accessible view into how AI can do more than just automate your business processes as data aggregation and machine processing becomes cheaper.
Excellent account of the current state of AI, and what to expect in the near future.
A good rigorous look at Artificial IntelligenceA rigorous look at the impact of AI in the economy and society. Takes a step back from the hype and helps to focus on the questions that matter.

A fairly basic, well-trodden treatise on the prediction potential of artificial intelligence, Prediction Machines refines its subject-matter in an overly simplistic, generalized manner, though for the reader without background in artificial intelligence the book can serve as a fruitful backdrop.

A quite disappointing read.. Informative, but not particularly thoughtful. The kind of book which simply “documented a lot of things I already know”. I expected a much profounder analysis if this is THE book to understand the AI economics.

An excellent book on AI. I have a solid economics and business background and I found this book to provide an excellent framework for thinking about AI. The book benefited from a number of good examples. Definitely worth reading, if you want a short introduction targeted at a layman.

Not too deep in the weeds. However, this is the right perspective. It's important to understand the usability and the limitations of machine learning in certain political climates. Really enjoyed the book!

A few very interesting insights from applying economic thinking to the idea that our ability to make predictions is getting better. A huge number of anecdotes I've heard before. This would have been better as a long form essay than it was padded out to book length.

This is a great book if you are unfamiliar with AI and how it’s currently applied. However, I feel it will be dated a year from now. Also, being a young person in tech, most of the book’s AI stories seemed like obvious use cases. I work in robotics and I think the topic was accurately covered.

I liked the economist viewpoint to AI. Leaves no room for hype and BS, but concentrates on putting the AI revolution in context of previous changes in human societies. Also, appreciated the authors’ expertise on the topic. This is one of the good AI books to read. 👆🏻

Solid book for technologists looking for a grounded introduction on how machine learning (and potentially, AI) can and will transform business in the next decade. It's light on math and theory, and instead heavily application focused.

basic but not meant to be a technical piece. Written by 3 economists to describe the pyramid of Prediction, Decision Making, Tools, Strategy, Society. Overall a balanced book for a layman trying to understand how ML/AI fits into today’s life.

economics + machine learning = amazing through an economic lens, the world makes so much more sense. this book did just that with machine learning & artificial intelligence. a must read for anyone looking to be a future leader in our AI-first world.

More like 3.5. While there are some easy to approach definitions and business considerations, it packages things up too neatly & stretches a bit in some places. Good book, but not the first place I’d start.

Alexa is more than a music player. Machines like Alexa, Apps like Fitbit, Smart Phones etc. our world is changing because of the data being collected, allowing learning better predictions and performance.

Great discussion of artificial intelligence. Very accessible to many audiences, and I think the economists viewpoint is very important for business and government people to consider. This helped me a lot to delve into this issue a bit.

The authors provide a framework for understanding the impact and implications of "cheap prediction" what this portends for decision making in general and the opportunities implied for businesses and society.

Good book for people who have no idea what AI does and how it is part of their life already. I found it to be repetitive. It does give glimpses into possible career choices that one can make and how to think about AI in one’s current career.

The perspective of an economist with regards to AI was interesting, which was the initial part of the book. Also the part on what AI can and cannot do. The rest felt repetitive. But overall a good bird’s eye view on AI specially for business leaders.

Perfect bell curve into AI. Explains 101 concepts, uses intriguing stories, then gives a few deep impact predictions. Only not 5 stars because it hasn’t stuck w me on a day by day, but highly recommended for someone trying to learn as a tech lay person.
Clearly written and argued, despite being fairly abstract.
Great book. Really refreshing. Economics the way it should be - helping to make sense of the world.  Need to start reading it again.
Interest perspective on how to view AI's impact.
Very good, more centered on prediction machines than general artificial intelligence. Well documented and well written. Would definitely recommend.
An uncommonly clear and hype-free explanation of what AI can and can't do, with plenty of advice for execs who are trying to get handle on this fast-emerging technology.
I’d recommend this book to anyone trying to understand AI, without getting into the technical details.
Not as eye-opening as I expected it to be. Some chapters read more like blog posts without real connections between subsequent chapters.
I think that if you have some knowledge of economics and AI, most of the book seems too general and without any concrete examples.
A handful of good points, but also several egregiously wrong ones. Not at all technical and several comments make you wonder how much the authors actually understand applications.
Clear overview of AI and it's potential impact and use.
Solid b school treatment of machine learning and ai. Informative and well organized.
Dry & uninteresting. The topic deserves better.

good for a 10000ft view of AI
It was ok for an easy read with a simple message. A light follow on to Pedro Domingos’s book, which is still my favourite book about ML.
Very well written. Some excellent applied examples.
Beautifully written, lucid and practical treatment.
Maybe good for someone with zero understanding of artificial intelligence.

Practical perspectives on what the advancements in AI and machine learning mean for business and society. Filled with interesting examples, stories and use cases.
Very informative.
Nice twist on AI - all about prediction. Reframed the topic for me
For beginners to understand and starters to step into AI, this book is a must read.
Nice easy overview of AI from an economics point of view
Excellent.I really liked how Ajay broke down the implications of AI across a business and society.An excellent blend of theory, pratice and humour. Would recommend.
This provides an excellent perspective on the current and future state of AI. Excellent!
Timely and clarifying
Decent book combining economics with AI thoughts
Somewhat repetitive at times. This book is an interesting read if you're interested in the economic impact of artificial intelligence (AI). Not very technical.
On the money
Good, but rather useless unless you want just the why and not the how. Nothing earth shattering.
Great book. A good background in prediction machines (artificial intelligence). Will listen again.
Very well written. Excellent examples.
This book accomplishes its aims - to demystify the current wave of software development and give the reader tools to analyze possible use cases. Well done!
Must read for anyone in tech or in business or wants to keep their job in the future.This is a no nonsense book on the real impacts of AI on business and individuals.
Without being technical, the book gives a good overview of the possible applications, economics and risks of AI.
A nice introduction to Artificial Intelligence. A good read for those interested in this field.
A must read, changes perception of the new worlds we are and will be surrounded by.
Fascinating ideas throughout, if you can stay awake to notice them.
A basic, but informative book. The AI Canvas is a good concept and can be easily applied as a checklist when looking through applying ML on business problems.
Good introductory book on the prediction side of AI. Raises lots of questions on future issues regarding AI
A must read for anyone interested in the basic applications of Artificial Intelligence in Business.
Engaging read and conceptualization of an AI future.
Great high-level overview of AI - I would recommend for anyone looking for an intro book to AI. Had the opportunity to meet the author which was exciting.
Great read for those who want to understand the applicability of artificial intelligence to business.
An interesting analysis of AI and the moral, ethical, political, and economic question that will need to be studied as we move forward into a more automated world.
Would be a good primer on AI for someone who’s lived in a cave for last ten years. Nothing new. Combo of well recorded tidbits from major publications and other similar business books.
very informative book about the fundamentals of AI. Found it to be a bit boring at the end.
